http://crataegus.com/portfolio/And definitely see our ridiculous video, above, which clearly proves we're not actors posing as bonsai artists. The outtakes / bloopers are maybe the best part, though, and you can see that in the Gallery...

How does this help?
The Villagers would like to share the beautiful art of bonsai with you. Your contribution will help in promoting bonsai outside of Japan. By helping us form the Portland Bonsai Village, you’re essentially making a huge contribution to education, art, a local economy, and the livelihood of nearly a dozen artisans, once our nifty programs are underway.
This is a big dream project. I know we are all contributing now to Nepal and other places struck by disaster where money is needed, I did so myself. But we also need other kinds of hope, so please support us, too.UPDATE! We've created a beautiful website with the funds raised by this campaign on Indiegogo, which you can see here:http://www.portlandbonsaivillage.com/#welcome-1
We're so excited to have such a beautiful online home...our sincerest thanks for all donors! AND YET ANOTHER UPDATE!First of all, thank you all for contributing to what is a successful and growing community effort. The campaign has been wildly successful, more than we dreamed possible. And we're now building on that to prove your trust in us.Something new:The Village Grants. As our primary and flagship program, the Village Grants assist local bonsai artists to bring their art to the public by funding engaging, educational projects. In January 2016, two of our Villagers, Matt Reel and Bobby Curttright, dreamed up a display show as an educational event, and will be receiving a Village Grant to assist them in their endeavors.We are essentially a non-profit, and with very low administrative costs (annual website hosting and accounting) almost all of your current donations will go to fund educational programs. Thank you all for making this vision a reality. It is now truly that: A bonsai community. And that's a new reality.
What will we do?

Along with our flagship program, the Village Grants, which are offered to Villagers who have dreamed up engaging, educational programs, here are things we'd like to offer in the future:



The Village Campus: Our ‘Bonsai Flight’, or sampler, as it were. Our doors open during the Campus in intensive mini-classes. Sample our various teachers and learn the art of bonsai~


The Village Co-Op: Products around the Village will be offered for sale at the Co-Op: Bonsai, pots, stands, tools, and everything else of the art ~


Village Dormitory: Our long-term goal of a dwelling in Portland where students, be they long-term apprentices or short-term students, may stay while they study with Villagers. Maybe that will be you!


Village Elementary: The Village brings bonsai into classrooms like Head Start to nurture the seed of beauty and responsibility in youth ~


Village Tours: Private and semi-private tours are offered to the nurseries and studios of Villagers to see them at work. We've already run a few, and they were a smash hit!



Can we do this?

Although we're quite a friendly mob of people, we're also pretty serious about what we do...check out a few of our websites:


crataegus.com
austinheitzmanfurniture.com
reelbonsai.wordpress.com

bonsaimirai.com
I've also been writing about the Village for a while on my blog:

http://crataegus.com/2013/10/22/the-portland-bonsai-village-tours-continue/
http://crataegus.com/2013/07/31/scenes-from-the-very-first-portland-bonsai-village-tour/
…and here's one of my wonky earlier posts about the Village, if you need a laugh today:
http://crataegus.com/2012/11/06/portland-bonsai-village-gets-on-the-design-board/


What inspired the Village idea? 
The Village was inspired by Omiya Bonsai
Village in Japan. Omiya’s history is the stuff of legend. Starting in the
early 1920’s about 20 bonsai masters went to Omiya to build their gardens. With
so many bonsai professionals in one place, Japan now had a ‘home’ for bonsai.
Anyone interested in the art knew that they could find a tree or a professional
service in Omiya Bonsai Village. Such a large flow of customers to Omiya brought
in business for everyone, took their work up a notch, and they were able to
develop specialties. Although many of the nurseries are now closed,
some of the most famous ones are still there. Portland Villagers like Matt
Reel, Ryan Neil, and Michael Hagedorn apprenticed under masters who themselves
studied in Omiya Bonsai Village, and so Portland Villagers are essentially
recreating the situation that nurtured their teachers in forming a new Village
in the United States. We are the 3rd generation from Omiya’s founders, now far
beyond the shores of Japan.



What do we need?
The money you donate to the Portland Bonsai Village will go to:

Village Grants, offered to Villagers who have dreamed up engaging, educational bonsai programs (the lion's share of donations received currently goes to this)
Running our future programs, listed above 

A great website (we've wooed top-notch designer Kathy Wu, who has done gorgeous work for big brands like Nike, Intel, Bridgeport Brewing, Jenny Craig, and the LA Marathon.) (paid for, THANK YOU)


Branding (Kathy) (paid for, THANK YOU)


Logo design (More Kathy) (paid for, THANK YOU)


Passports for the tours (paid for, THANK YOU)


Professional photography for the website (paid for, THANK YOU)


Deposits for bus tours (paid for, THANK YOU)


Booth rentals (paid for, THANK YOU)


Banner and promotional materials (paid for, THANK YOU)


Your contribution will help jumpstart us and will bring about great new bonsai programs that you can take part in. (thank you thank you thank you thank you thank you)

story: Hi! im chloe! im a student in the good ol PNW, and im struggling. I'm never one to ask for this kind of help, but im in a dire need. My car, which is my only mode of transportation, has a huge leak in it which messed up a lot of the car, and is going to cost around 1K to fix. I am in school, i work part time, and i take care of my grandmother so having my car is a necessity for everything else in my life. but i really cant afford it, so im looking to the internet for help. even $1 will help, please consider!!! thank u for reading this!

story:
Tannery Bend Beerworks

GET IT WHILE SUPPLIES LAST!!!!

BENDERS CLUB- DURING CAMPAIGN ONLY, $100 FOR A LIFETIME MEMBERSHIP! EQUAL TO A FREE BEER EVERY 4 FILLS, PAYS FOR ITSELF IN JUST A FEW MONTHS! Only 48 available, and after campaign closes membership will be $100 per year. 

FOUNDERS CLUB- DURING CAMPAIGN ONLY, $450 FOR A TWO YEAR MEMBERSHIP! TWO YEARS OF BOTTLE CLUB MEMBERSHIP AND TWO ANNUAL 4-COURSE BEER DINNERS! LIFETIME OF VIP PERKS! Only 25 memberships available, and no more available after campaign closes.

NAME ON THE BAR- YOUR ONLY CHANCE TO GET PERMANENTLY HONORED AT TANNERY BEND!

UNTIL THE END OF CAMPAIGN ALL DONATIONS OF $100 OR MORE GET A LOGO T-SHIRT AND ALL DONATIONS OF $300 OR MORE GET A FREE HOODY!!!!!!!!!!

Since we got together and concocted this beer-inspired project, many friends and family have asked how they can contribute to bringing more beer to downtown Napa, which is why we've decided to create a crowd funding campaign on Indiegogo for Tannery Bend Beerworks. As partners, we (Matt Cromwell, Tyler Rodde, and Lauren Duncan) are opening Tannery Bend Beerworks to serve the local Napa community with delicious and intriguing beers born from a unique collaboration between a Brewer and a Chef all presented in a warm and welcoming setting overseen by a master of hospitality.

The brewery and tasting room located at 101 S. Coombs Street in Napa will open in winter of 2016 within a 1,500-square-foot space that has room to fit a maximum of 25 people with 10 bar seats.


Making this dream a reality has taken a lot of hard work. The three of us have been working on this project for several years, investing time and money as we encountered many starts and stops over the years. We have sought out different business models, various scales and multiple locations before finding a home at 101 S. Coombs Street. 

It is now that we call on the community to help us cross the finish line. It is your support that will take us from garage brewing to doors open and pints flowing. It's important for us to get the community involved in this initial stage. If you believe like we believe, we will build something great!

Matt Cromwell, Tyler Rodde, and Lauren Duncan


Going Around the Bend

We want the community to help fund the brewery that they want. We've broken down what we need to get it out of the brite (tank) and into the glass.

Of course, we have tons of cool perks that you can check out along the sidebar, but really, the further this campaign goes, the better brewery we are able to build for you to enjoy. We want this brewery to be by the people, for the people - come be our people!

PLEASE SEND US A MESSAGE WITH YOUR SIZE FOR ANY CLOTHING
(We'd love it if everyone can pick up their perks at the brewery so we can properly thank them, but if you're not local and would still like to contribute just get in touch and we'll figure out a way to get you your swag!)


Bending the Rules

We are strong believers in our community, something that we have tried to recognize at Oenotri over the years. Oenotri is a place to bring family and friends for great food and wine. With Tannery Bend Beerworks, we want to extend that vision by bringing Napa together in a space filled with warmth, comfort and great beer. With your initial help, we will create a craft brewery that Napa and its neighbors can love and stand behind.


As you have probably noticed, it is truly an exciting time to be a beer lover. Up and down the West Coast, smaller brewers are being afforded the chance to create incredible beers, something we wholeheartedly celebrate. We look forward to adding Tannery Bend Beerworks to the conversation.

Our collaboration between brewer and chef allows for an unique perspective on palate and ingredients. Over the years, we have studied and explored the juxtaposition between the culinary and brewing worlds, finding ways to bring them together. Whether it be tweaking traditional recipes or coming up with original concepts, we know that this compelling voice brings something new to craft brewing.


Bending an Ear

The word is already getting out!


Napa Valley Register- Craft Beer to Start Flowing From Napa Nano-Brewery


SF Gate- Napa nano-brewery, Tannery Bend Beerworks, on tap from Oenotri chef Tyler Rodde

Napa Valley Register- Small-batch 'nanobrewery' coming to Napa

San Francisco Eater- Oenotri Collaborating With Tannery Bend Beerworks For Upcoming Napa Nano-Brewery


On a Bender

Getting up and running is the biggest obstacle - building a brewery is expensive. Everything has a price tag and everything ends up costing more than you think it will. Creating a brewery that people are proud of is even more pricey and that’s why we’re asking for your help. 

More money not only means a better product, but more efficient production with less waste. Helping us do this right means we get to make the brewery that much more environmentally responsible, and that’s important to all of us. Furthermore, we believe that a business, especially a brewery, should be an active participant in its community. Beyond being a meeting place for family and friends, we want Tannery Bend to be a source of jobs for Napa and a place where charities and organizations can hold fundraisers. We look forward to giving back to the organizations that look out for Napa. To get there, though, we have to have your support.


Who Is the Tannery Bend Team?

Glad you asked, we are:

Tyler Rodde
Tyler Rodde turned his attention to the culinary arts after earning his bachelor's degree in economics from the University of Southern California. A short stint in culinary school and a creperie opening in Hollywood later, he moved back to northern California, where he honed his skills as a chef and operator in several restaurants throughout the Bay Area. In 2010, he returned to his Napa Valley roots to open Oenotri, a southern-Italian restaurant with a daily-changing menu. Driven by a passion for handcrafted food and showcasing the freshest local ingredients, Tyler continues to expand his role in the community by managing a four acre culinary garden which grows most of the produce for Oenotri. 

                                                   

Lauren Duncan
Lauren Duncan grew up in the Bay Area, where she found her passion for hospitality early, working childhood summers at the register of a family-owned neighborhood yogurt store and coffee shop. After attending the University of California, Santa Barbara, she returned to the restaurant business, working as Director of Public Relations and event coordinator for the local Harbor Restaurant group, bringing her into contact with every aspect of the guest experience. Upon returning to the San Francisco Bay Area, Lauren helped to open a variety of restaurants and bars in San Francisco proper and the East Bay, furthering honing her skills in developing outstanding service and great guest experiences. In 2010 she contributed her extensive experience to the opening of Oenotri where she currently is both General Manager as well as co-owner with husband Tyler Rodde.

                                       

Matt Cromwell

Matt Cromwell was born and raised in Napa, and has worked at Silverado Brewing Company and Napa Smith Brewery within the Napa Valley. He graduated from the brewing program at the Siebel Institute of Technology in Chicago and loves experimenting with beers, exploring new interpretations of traditional styles and interesting ways to use the best local products available. Matt's goal has always been to bring the taste of the great beer cultures of Belgium, Germany, and Ireland to downtown and to elevate Napa beer to its rightful place alongside the valley's wine culture.

                                        


Be a Bender

Money isn't the only way you can contribute:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the share tools below.

We don't expect everyone to contribute financially, but we would love it if you would help spread the word. If you can help get people excited about our mission, then some awesome beers are that much closer to pouring in downtown Napa. We thank you for your generous support. Cheers!

story:
Food Hacking Base in Hamburg during 32c3

As at many other events we will come together again during 32c3 in Hamburg to share our love for food, drink and bio hacking. Please note that this year we are not permitted by CCC orga to organize any practical food&drink activities in the Congress Center Hamburg (CCH) building. We therefore plan to run our food&drink events at nearby location called Centro Sociale which is around 23 minutes of walk from the congress center, simultaneously we will do variety of other non prohibited activities at the cch. We are sorry for the inconvenience, please note that we will be taking the heaviest burden doing our best to provide what we helped to integrate into the hacker movement and what therefore needs to continue to be part of the hacker events. This campaign will fund our activities during 32c3 and bring our budget to the plus numbers for 2016 which is very important for us!


What are we going to do?

Even with restrictions mentioned above we will be serving as a hub for people who are into the food, drink and bio. At the congress building you can meet us at our spot where you can spend time with us discussing variety of topics around food&drink, you can also join us in activities like experimental incubator build up, bio hacking etc which should be more practical. We will prepare a variety of recipes and workshop manuals which we can go through in theory and we hope to further build up our small library of books which we really think you should check out!


If you are really into what we are, with bit of extra walk you can join us for our food&drink events like cheese rendezvous, beer or whisky tasting, kombucha workshop etc. Where you make one step we will do two. Please check info about our events and pay good attention to where they are happening this year! From the extra projects we can mention small short book/booklet with some of our top recipes, manuals and maybe story or two will be shared with you. We will update you on this project during the campaign. Algoldor (Frantisek) will prepare Kvasir Diary 2015 which will be first step to a short publication on the probiotic brewing available to everyone open source based online, and specially for you in print if you claim it.


To make it simple

If you have supported us in the past you have our thanks, if you can please do so again! For the ones who did not chip in yet and would like to this is a great moment. We have had a great year, invested in lots of equipment and gear (including 2 large tents and lots of equipment) which we will be using in years to come but we are also still borrowing a trailer to get ourselves around. We we will have to pay at least symbolically for the Centro Sociale venue where we run our food&drink events so every little helps. Part of the resources which we get from this campaign and mostly during the event will go towards making the trailer truly ours and bringing our budget into the plus numbers so we have a nice start for 2016!


Bitcoins - we are very happy to accept Bitcoins (more than any other currencies to be honest), please use this wallet!

Bitcoin account address: 1Ph2ce4rUZei5Bz9GXESAHduczBY2QP2FT

story:
Every business needs to sell something... Not everyone knows how to do it.


PromoUrbe it's the new "red line" to your costumers, giving you the opportunity to connect with them directly, get to know their habits and most important, give you all the tools you need to achieve your sales goals and increase your market day by day. What do we mean with "directly"? Simple, you need to communicate something to your base costumers (hot promotion, brand new product, a 30 min discount... whatever you need!), then you go to your PromoUrbe Admin Panel, write  down the message and add some art and that's it! In less than 5 minutes all of them will get your promotion right in their pockets! 

But wait.... that's not totally new... right? Well, the fact that PromoUrbe NEVER expose or compromises any personal data of the users (like any Fanpage on Facebook or WhatsApp) makes a HUGE difference for them and brings a totally new perspective to this scheme.


With the actual tools and methods, small companies are losing a lot of money and resources while trying to communicate any news to their clients, contact with them or advertise new products or hot promotions. Besides than the fact that promoting on Facebook or by chats doesn't work as fast or massive as you could wish.



Now, with PromoUrbe we are giving to all the small and micro companies an alternative and ideal pack of tools for communicating, self-promoting, design small advertising campaigns and receive the feedback from their costumers... ALMOST IN REAL TIME! 



But not only that! PromoUrbe includes Loyalty Programs, Different types of Promotions, Private Rating Systems and a lot more tools to help you to increase and maintain your costumers base day by day.



So, does the world needs PromoUrbe?


Definitely, YES. But... Why are we so sure?

PromoUrbe it's not just a digital platform full of tools to improve your sales and connect you DIRECTLY with your clients. It's also a complete group of professionals  working for your company. How is that? Well, inside PromoUrbe there will be designers, photographers, coaches and everything you need to improve your business every single day, offering packages with their services at very competitive cost. This way, PromoUrbe will become the ultimate tool for your business.

With a Web Admin Panel (for the business' owner) and apps (for the costumers) on every main platform, PromoUrbe will be so easy and friendly to use. How easy it will be? Well, we have 50+ years old people testing the development. If they find something confusing or hard to use, we just redesign it as many times as needed so it becomes as intuitive as make a simple phone call.


The Team.



Where are we now?


We are a small Development Studio, with limited resources. The complete project, which includes PromoUrbe development (web admin and native Android/iOS apps), the advertising and communication campaign and the administration of the sales force, represents a very important spending for our Company and we can not afford  it without risking our day by day and families.



We are near to the final stage of the development, almost ready to launch the digital platform, but we need all your help for the last steps of the project (the most important of all, we think), because out there, the world it's full of great projects and ideas which never were well communicated to the public and then vanish on the forgotten.



We need all your help... in any way you can!


Yes, and not just by helping on the campaing. You can also help us a lot, telling all your friends about us, so we can reach our goal and release PromoUrbe as soon as possible.

Thanks a lot for your help and for giving us a chance to make our dream come true.
story_txt:
Every business needs to sell something... Not everyone knows how to do it. 
PromoUrbe it's the new "red line" to your costumers, giving you the opportunity to connect with them directly, get to know their habits and most important, give you all the tools you need to achieve your sales goals and increase your market day by day. What do we mean with "directly"? Simple, you need to communicate something to your base costumers (hot promotion, brand new product, a 30 min discount... whatever you need!), then you go to your PromoUrbe Admin Panel, write  down the message and add some art and that's it! In less than 5 minutes all of them will get your promotion right in their pockets! 
But wait.... that's not totally new... right? Well, the fact that PromoUrbe NEVER expose or compromises any personal data of the users (like any Fanpage on Facebook or WhatsApp) makes a HUGE difference for them and brings a totally new perspective to this scheme.

With the actual tools and methods, small companies are losing a lot of money and resources while trying to communicate any news to their clients, contact with them or advertise new products or hot promotions. Besides than the fact that promoting on Facebook or by chats doesn't work as fast or massive as you could wish.



Now, with PromoUrbe we are giving to all the small and micro companies an alternative and ideal pack of tools for communicating, self-promoting, design small advertising campaigns and receive the feedback from their costumers... ALMOST IN REAL TIME! 




But not only that! PromoUrbe includes Loyalty Programs, Different types of Promotions, Private Rating Systems and a lot more tools to help you to increase and maintain your costumers base day by day.





    So, does the world needs PromoUrbe? 



Definitely, YES. But... Why are we so sure?

PromoUrbe it's not just a digital platform full of tools to improve your sales and connect you DIRECTLY with your clients. It's also a complete group of professionals  working for your company. How is that? Well, inside PromoUrbe there will be designers, photographers, coaches and everything you need to improve your business every single day, offering packages with their services at very competitive cost. This way, PromoUrbe will become the ultimate tool for your business.
With a Web Admin Panel (for the business' owner) and apps (for the costumers) on every main platform, PromoUrbe will be so easy and friendly to use. How easy it will be? Well, we have 50+ years old people testing the development. If they find something confusing or hard to use, we just redesign it as many times as needed so it becomes as intuitive as make a simple phone call.



The Team.



    Where are we now?
 
We are a small Development Studio, with limited resources. The complete project, which includes PromoUrbe development (web admin and native Android/iOS apps), the advertising and communication campaign and the administration of the sales force, represents a very important spending for our Company and we can not afford  it without risking our day by day and families.




We are near to the final stage of the development, almost ready to launch the digital platform, but we need all your help for the last steps of the project (the most important of all, we think), because out there, the world it's full of great projects and ideas which never were well communicated to the public and then vanish on the forgotten.






We need all your help... in any way you can!
 

Yes, and not just by helping on the campaing. You can also help us a lot, telling all your friends about us, so we can reach our goal and release PromoUrbe as soon as possible.
Thanks a lot for your help and for giving us a chance to make our dream come true.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to look at our page. We are so grateful for any support at all! 



                                                            (Front Stage, 2014)


Camp Questionmark's crews work incredibly hard year round to bring some of the best Artists & Bass Music experiences from around the world to the Playa. 

As Burning Man 2015 approaches, we find ourselves without a kitchen & now need to rebuild it from the ground up. Any donations will help keep our very hard working crews able to prepare food safely in a kitchen. 



                                             (Our Crew, building through the night)


Our Crew is responsible for every aspect of the camp & stage. From building & managing, to operating & cleaning up. This takes immense effort, and doesn't even take into account all of the work happens before and after the event. We would love you to take a peek at our video so that you can see a glimpse of how some of this hard work comes together. 

Without our hard working crew we wouldn't be able to make this magical thing happen each year & we really want to make sure they all have a safe kitchen to keep them healthy.


                                                 (Working in the sun and smiling)


Camp Questionmark is home to Hard Workers, Dj's, Musicians, Producers, Dancers, Performers, Fire Spinners, Volunteers and many visual artists that contribute their time and creativity to the burn each year within the camp and throughout the entire event. 

Please help our crew with a way to rebuild the kitchen so that they can prepare their meals safely & focus on keeping everything running perfectly each night. Several members of our crew have put forth some of their art work that we would love to give you in exchange for your support. You can view them in the perks section. 

Thank you very much!


                                    We love you! Thank you for your support!

story:
Online Condom Stores are Lame

Hi all, Brian here.

I need your help in starting a a website called Prot-Me.com.  It will be an online store specializing in contraceptives which combines desecrate buying with a deep and satisfying amount of information to go along with each product.  The ability to buy contraceptives online is nothing new, but often what you find are simple storefronts with minimal information about the products.  If you want to know more, you'll need to look elsewhere.  Not only that, none of these sites provides information about alternative forms of contraceptives, especially those meant for the female body, such as spermicide, in-condoms, etc.

Prot-Me.com is Different!

Not only will every item sold contain a detailed description of what the product is made of, how effective it is at preventing pregnancy and STD transmission, Dos and Don'ts, as well as instructions on how to use the product, but there will also be video demonstrations for every product sold on the site!  And I don't mean just a simple video showing the product with a simple description.  I will use actual demonstrations on props to demonstrate how to use the product, how well does it fit, etc.  If I have to, I will do each and every video demonstrating this, but I am hoping to find additional people to help and add variety.  


My Goals with This Campaign (How You Can Help!)

To be honest, I need as much help as I can get.  I still need funds to order inventory and purchase props.  The site is currently under construction, but I could use some help paying for a subscription on Bigcommerce.com, which is where I'll be hosting the site.  I am capable of developing the site myself, but that is going to take some time, so it would also be great to have a financial buffer to help pay the bills while I dedicate time to this project.  As such, my goal is $10,000.  I feel this is reasonable and would provide me with a great start.  

Stretch Goals (I Won't Make the Obvious Joke)

$20,000 would enable me to offer greater service right off the bat, such as more product diversity and better shipping options.  I have my eye on a service called Shipwire, which stores and ships your products for you and would allow me to get people's purchases out faster and more professionally.  

With $35,000 I could begin to look outside my skillset to find additional talent who could help make this project an even greater success.  I could find someone to help with the site by providing some custom art and graphics I may not have the ability to create.  I don't have my own logo yet, so I would love it if I could get someone artistic to help me with that.  Also I could pay for additional demonstrators for my products so it's not just me playing with fake dicks all day.  Also I could move this production out of the basement and into a studio which could double as an office.

Finally, my dream of dreams would be to raise a solid $50,000.  With this, I could get an actual office.  If I'm having Shipwire handle my inventory, then I don't really need a ton of office space.  With a room for computer space to work on the site and a separate room for filming, my needs will be met.  I could even get some more professional filming equipment, such as a more professional camera and better lighting and sound.  

Perky Perks! (I tried...)

This a very hard project to imagine perks for, so I am totally, 100% open to suggestions here.  Here is some of what I've worked out so far:

$1 - My Non-Specific but Altogether Heartfelt Gratitude  -  If 10,000 people see this campaign, and if each of them just donate 1 dollar... I still won't quite make goal because of Indiegogo fees, but it'll sure make it close the total amount and would be absolutely wonderful!  

$5 - My More Specific, Handwritten Gratitude  -  I'll send you a letter with my thanks.

$20 - Letter Plus Sample of Choice  -  What sort of sample would you like?  It can be a condom, or a dental dam, or an in-condom (normally called a female condom).  All of these will be available on my site, BTW.  

$69 - Cool Stuff Bundle  -  Okay, sometimes it's important to be predictable.  Nevertheless, at this level, I'll send you the aforementioned letter of thanks along with a bundle of assorted products, such as condoms, lubes, etc, with a bit of an "Oral" theme.  I'll communicate with you ahead of time to make sure there are no issues or if you'd like some customization.

The bundle I work out will serve as a model later on for something I can sell on the site.

$500 - Year's Supply!  -  Contraceptives are often cheaper when purchased in bulk.  At this donation amount, a bulk purchase of your choice will be sent to you all at once or parceled out over the course of a year.  We can work out the details, so I'll be communicating with you if you go for this perk.  To keep costs down, I will only be allowing 10 of these.

$10,000 - Be a Presenter in a Video!  -  Would you like to have the chance to present?  Be in a video and demonstrate the product of your choice!  There will be a set of standards the video should adhere to, but we can work it out.  

Not very many Perks?  I know, as I said, I'm having trouble coming up with perks for this, so I will take suggestions.

My Pet Passion

I remember in high school learning about different kinds of contraceptives for the first time.  I found the information fascinating.  And I don't even mean in a weird, or sexual way.  I just wanted to know more about the history and different types, etc.  Since then, I've educated myself more and more and have kept up on new developments.  It's only been recently that I actually started purchasing these products for my personal use and realized that buying them, in a word, sucks.  It's probably a whole lot better now than it used to be, but it still sucks.  Stores have a limited selection and even more limited knowledge.  Online stores are either places to buy bulk discount condoms, or Amazon.  Neither have much in the way of information.  The idea I have here is a way to help people make informed choices about what is best for them.  A lot of this hinges on the demonstration videos.  If people can actually see how the condom looks on various sizes or how to apply the spermicide, etc, they can feel more comfortable buying.  Plus I feel that it would be a lot of fun.

It is my hope that you can help me make this a reality so we can have more informed buyers and keep people safe and protected.  

 Protect yourself.

story:
This is going to be awesome!

Each year at Open Source Bridge, the main conference community space is the hacker lounge. This year, a group of us decided we'd like to turn the Hacker Lounge into a sparkle pony palace. The catch: we need your help to fund it!

What is Open Source Bridge? It's an annual conference for people who participate in open source, held June 23-26 in Portland, OR. The conference focuses on building stronger open source projects and communities by sharing what we know, and exploring our rights and responsibilities. The Hacker Lounge is the space at the heart of the conference, where people hang out, rest, discuss the talks, and show off what they're working on.

What this will support

$5000 would buy a lot of sparkly things! Beyond our decorating needs, our goal is to support the conference as much as we can. We can do that by creating a welcoming, hospitable common space at the conference (and pretty too!), and contributing additional funds to support the needs of this four-day event.

Did you know?

Open Source Bridge is an all volunteer-run conference produced by Stumptown Syndicate, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to creating resilient, radically inclusive tech and maker communities. Donations are tax deductible.

Spread the sparkle pony word

You can help us by telling people about Open Source Bridge and our plans for the Hacker Lounge. We only have 10 days to raise the money and make this happen, so tweets, emails, links in Slack/IRC, and any other outreach you can do will make a difference. See you at this year's Open Source Bridge!

story:
Rosa needs us

As you may have heard it, tragedy has struck our good friend Rosa in the early hours of Monday, September 22nd 2014. An electrical failure within the walls has set her kitchen and bathroom ablaze. Her home is a total loss and will have to be rebuilt. Some colleagues and I have personally witnessed the extent of the devastation during recent visits. Rosa is very proud and is not asking for help. However, I believe that she would welcome our selfless support and affection as she has done so for us for so many years.

Consequently, I have started this Indiegogo campaign to lend support to our friend and help her get back on track as much as such a thing is possible. She has insurance for her familial triplex but her home unit insurance is disputed. She really needs our help.

Thank you!

Harold Isaac

Rosa a besoin de nous

Comme vous l'avez probablement appris, la tragédie a frappé notre bonne amie Rosa dans les petites heures du lundi 22 Septembre 2014. Une défaillance électrique dans les murs a provoqué un violent incendie dans sa cuisine et sa salle de bain. Sa demeure est une perte totale et devra être reconstruite. Certains de mes collègues et moi avons été personnellement témoins de l'ampleur de la dévastation lors de récentes visites. Rosa est très fière et ne demande pas d'aide. Cependant, je crois qu'elle serait très heureuse d'obtenir notre soutien et notre affection, comme elle l'a fait pour nous pendant tant d'années. 

Par conséquent, j'ai démarré cette campagne Indiegogo afin d'apporter du soutien à notre amie et l'aider à se remettre en selle autant que faire se peut. Elle dispose d'une assurance pour son triplex familial mais son assurance individuelle est contestée. Elle a vraiment besoin de notre aide.

Merci!

Harold Isaac

story:
Project Re-Build Future 

Rick and Muriel Larrison, St Petersburg Florida are Grandparents of Dane Stewart. Dane is a 17 year old with Cerebral Palsy, Spinal Scoliosis who they have cared for close to ten years. Dane has needed constant care while growing from a young boy to man-hood, all done in a space that seems to be shrinking. 2010 brought another surgery this time with titanium rods and 3 inch hip screws – he grew 4 inches this day alone.. By now Dane has limited access to the house, he spends most of his time in the living room, his chair only able to reach his bedroom and part of the kitchen. His nurses have to move him to a shower chair to be able to get to the bathroom – simply washing his hands, brushing his teeth or just looking in the mirror, things that we take for granted, are not experienced. September 2014, after exhausting all avenues of help, Muriel and Rick started “Project Re-build Future”

March 2015 Dave will turn 18. Muriel and Rick are determined to provide Dane freedom for his birthday. An old Florida room, filled with Dane’s extra chairs and supplies, will provide the space. Being something they have wanted to do for years now they will tell you every square inch of the project – right down to the $60,000 estimate.

Volunteer Society of America is a 501(c)(3) built around Giving to eliminate homelessness, hunger and heartache One Person - One Project - One Community at a time


Volunteer Society of America 

Giving to eliminate Homelessness, Hunger and Heartache 

One Person - One Project - One Community at a time

story:
The dream behind the project is quite straightforward; it is a bridge to bring together people from all corners of the globe to instantly communicate with each other. This App is simplistic in design, easy to navigate and is Android based, a platform that is way ahead of any other mobile operating system.

The advantage of being structured on Android is that it interacts seamlessly with Google maps, a vital factor if locations have to be pinpointed across the world with great accuracy.

Overview of the App

The App basically has two modes. In the first, an OCR camera will read the selected address text, bring up the location through Google maps and enable sending an SMS. In the second, there is an option to take a picture and then proceed with the same process. There are a number of important objectives that can be met through this app. However, a detailed look at how the app works will be in order.

First Mode “Capture Address”

After opening the app, the screen will show “Capture Address” and “Capture View”.


Select “Capture Address” option and a popup screen will ask for the chosen language – “Hebrew” or “English”.



Choosing this option will automatically open the OCR (Optical Character Recognition) camera that can simultaneously carry out machine-readable and human readable text functions.

The camera will recognise the text that has been typed in and will open Google map.




The location matching the text will be shown on the map along with a “Send SMS” button which will take the user straight to the Contacts list and particulars where the message needs to be sent. It’s so easy to fix up a date! “I’m here. Let’s meet at …”

The user can even take pictures of the address from a newspaper, website, computer or a notebook. For example, a picture is taken of a location in Hong Kong and you are in Israel. When the Google map pops up, the destination place “Hong Kong” will be shown in green and the place of origin, Israel in blue.

Second Mode Capture View

In this mode, a picture has to be taken




The location given and the same process as the first mode has to be followed, right up to “Send SMS”.

This mode can be very useful and an example will bear this out. Suppose that the police are in search of a dangerous criminal on the “Wanted” list and you see him suddenly standing right in front of you at a bus stop.

Take a picture, “Capture View”, put in the particulars in SMS and send it to the authorities. It can be anything, even a missing poodle!

Share Option

One of the important features of this app is the “Share” option. It is very easy to navigate among the apps list present in the mobile device. A share button opens up the list. Simply select an app and navigate there. This seamless steering between apps enables the user to go in for a wide range of functions on related and applicable apps. However, it has to be kept in mind that this is subject to the extent of services offered by the connectivity provider.

Who We ARE?

We are LookApp a small development company ,

We love creating apps and websites !

And of course Music!

Funding

We are very excited about this project as it helps bring the world closer together. Places are located at lightning speed and lines of communications through SMS can be established immediately. A system of rewards and incentives has been structured by us in proportion to the investments made and very attractive goodies specific to the app is being put together for distribution. Those in the top brackets will even get to install this very useful app even before it is released commercially. Now, that’s something!

story:
The Millennial Trains Project (MTP) is an award-winning series of crowdfunded transcontinental train journeys for young innovators to explore America’s new frontiers. This an officially-approved campaign for MTP's May 2015 journey.

To get on board, applicants design a project to advance across the communities where our train stops and then race to be among the first 20 applicants to reach their $5k crowdfunding goal. The applicant's project is described below.

***

I'm Engaged in a Nutshell: I'm Engaged  (IE) puts human faces to the challenges facing America's 6.7 million disengaged youth, better known as Opportunity Youth. Through success story profiles, this project will highlight effective ways to address their challenges, while simultaneously combatting the stereotype of disengaged youth as lost causes. 

IE's Vision of the Future: IE is focused on a future where all youth feel confident in and capable of self-determining their futures. IE embodies the perception of a minimized opportunity and skills gap through sharing Opportunity Youth success stories and the support networks that helped make re-engagement possible.  

The Problem: 6.7 million Opportunity Youth equals much more than 6.7 million in unrealized hopes, lost opportunities, and billions in increased costs. With lots of focus on early childhood development and necessary efforts to prevent school dropout rates, those who have already left tend to be overlooked, except perhaps by the criminal justice system. 

Opportunity Youth  are individuals between the ages of 16 and 24 who are neither in school nor working. In the United States, there is estimated to be 6.7 million Opportunity Youth; that’s nearly 20% of all individuals ages 16 to 24. Over 60% of youth crime is attributed to Opportunity Youth, which perpetuates increased spending on incarceration and victim services instead of needed education and job training.  

While re-engaging Opportunity Youth is not without its challenges, there is tremendous opportunity. This population represents the chance to develop talent at a time when America faces a significant skills gap. According to a 2011 study conducted by McKinsey Global Institute, 64% of American companies cannot find suitable talent to fill open positions, and we're not just talking about a shortage of computer engineers but welders, nutritionists, and nurse's aids are among the top positions in demand to name a few. In addition to this skills gap and the moral dilemma of significant numbers of the youth population being unable to realize their full potential, there are significant costs associated with failing to address increasing rates of disengagement. In 2011 alone, lost revenues from a lack of productive workers and increased social services cost taxpayers $93 billion. 

While some view these youth as lost causes, a recent study conducted by the Civic Enterprises and America’s Promise Alliance confirmed many Opportunity Youth remain optimistic about their futures and have concrete goals. 77% of Opportunity Youth believe their future is their own responsibility and success depends on their own efforts. 75% are confident they will eventually be able to achieve their life goals. In other words, these are not hopeless cases.

The Solution: Numerous studies outline macro issues from the growing class divide to shifts in social mobility to the growing income gap, but what do these challenges look like to those that are facing them the most, and how can we address these challenges in real-time for the rising generation of America’s workforce? The answer is through the examples of those successfully on the path to re-engagement.

Through the Millennial Train Project, I will be interviewing and profiling Opportunity Youth on track to reconnect with education, work and civic life. Each profile will also highlight the community programs and services used to assist in their efforts. The I'm Engaged  live blog will be a bank of lived experiences, both successes and challenges as well as unfulfilled needs. Not only will this initiative put faces and real stories to the struggles of America’s Opportunity Youth but it will also provide real-time feedback for community programs and services with guiding knowledge for future program development.The I'm Engaged  live blog will feature all profile content leading up to and during the journey. In addition to the project blog site, I will be curating corresponding I'm Engaged  Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram feeds with highlights of the journey alongside an e-newsletter featuring daily profiles for those that register on the I'm Engaged  site. 

The Process: Leading up to the MTP journey, I will identify community organizations at the forefront of re-engaging Opportunity Youth. Each of these organizations will be profiled on the I'm Engaged  site. Through these organizations, I will connect with individual success stories. My interview format will be designed based on pre-MTP discussions with program developers and field experts. At each stop I will conduct five one-hour interviews with pre-selected individuals. Each day a new profile will be added to the I'm Engaged site. At the end of the MTP,  I'm Engaged  will consist of 30 Opportunity Youth success stories and 30 corresponding answers to one of our nation's most pressing social challenges. 

Important notice for supporters: If this campaign is among the first 20 to reach its $5,000 goal, all funds raised will go to Millennial Train Project, which is a tax-deductible 501(c)3 organization. These funds underwrite the costs of the journey and its associated programming, transportation, and hospitality fees. If I am not among the first 20 applicants to reach the crowd-funding goal, no supporters will be charged.

story:
The 4th Annual Beer Die tournament is almost upon us. With a large distance to travel and recent expenses taking priority (buying a car, traveling for interviews), it would take a miracle for me to make it back east for the event. I missed the 3rd tournament due to work, and I'd like to make it the only one I miss. 

Please help fund my way to the tournament. If I can get the money I will need, I will commit to documenting the event, taking pictures all weekend. Visit my blog to see some of my previous work: http://toughasheck.tumblr.com

If I somehow exceed my goal, those funds will be put back into the event for food, beer and maybe even awards. 

Thank you!

story:
"The next time someone asks, "How can we feed the world without these industrial monoculture systems?" I want people to be able to point to our farm and say, "That's how."

Help us continue to pioneer new techniques for feeding the world while caring for it.  Our plan includes perennial tree cropping combined with multi-species grazing smack dab in the heartland of industrial agriculture - Iowa. 

Who we are:


Chad and Danelle Stamps here! Along with our three children, we operate
The Stamps Family Farm in southern Iowa. In 2009 when we moved to the
farm we knew we wanted to do things differently. Caring for the land while educating others is a primary mission of our farm.

We began our farm dream as customers, as we learned more about where
our food comes from we naturally moved towards becoming farmers
ourselves, but without the familial or community connections and support that most generational farmers have, we have had to build that trust and community from scratch. We hope to use our farm and our experiences to educate and build community for others who want to farm, and help mentor them as others have mentored us.

We operate the farm profitably each year without compromising the principles that led us to Permaculture and regenerative farming. Along the way we have improved our techniques as we learned, adapting our initial plans for an apple orchard to a more regenerative model that incorporates perennial crops, animals, and community outreach. In 2014, Chad completed Geoff Lawton's online Permaculture Design Course, along with other workshops in preparation for our most recent major commitment to the farm and it's future - in October, Chad left the corporate job he'd worked at for 15 years to focus on the farm full time.

What We're Doing:


When we moved here in 2009, eleven of our forty acres had been in corn and bean rotation for the last several decades.  The rest is taken up by either water or woods.  For most conventional farmers that's considered a poor use of land, and indeed, that's why the land was being sold.  For us, the water and trees were the major selling points.  The beans had just been harvested and the earth was bare.  We let the native grasses and weeds grow, cutting and allowing them to regrow, and have gradually introduced animal grazing onto the land.  That care shows.  Six years later the pastures are now extremely diverse and of good quality, and ripe to begin planting the trees that are the next phase of the land restoration.

The money raised here will go directly to planting trees and installing the infrastructure necessary to support them.  Tree plantings of apples, plums, peaches, hazels, chestnuts, and mulberries will be interspersed with black locust and other trees designed to fix nitrogen and nurse the main tree crops into production at small intervals designed to be thinned as necessary.  These trees will be planted along swales running on contour across what are now our main pasture areas.  Fencing will protect the trees from the livestock that will be grazed down the aisles created by these tree lines.  If we are successful, we'll be able to put 1000 trees into the ground.  Every $20 we receive will be able to plant one tree and install the necessary fencing and other infrastructure necessary to care for it long into the future.

These trees will be a cornerstone for showing a future generation of farmers how we can feed the world without destroying it.  Our future projects include building a test garden and classroom/community space, holding workshops, and hosting retreats. We hope our farm can also be an incubator for others' farm dreams and small businesses. Teaching others about Permaculture is our lifelong calling and we hope to be doing it for a long time.  We've begun this outreach already by holding the first meeting of the Central Iowa Permaculture Guild. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute dollars, your voice and support is critical to our project and to educating about Permaculture and resilient agriculture.  Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!

story:
Each year, we fundraise in June to send childcare volunteers + workshop leaders to participate in the Allied Media Conference. This conference helps us connect to other Childcare Collectives + is a crucial part of sustaining the work we do in Chicago. Please help us get there! 

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

Who is the Chicago Childcare Collective (ChiChiCo)?

ChiChiCo, formed in 2008, is a group of volunteers who support the participation of parents and guardians, especially mothers, in racial and economic justice work. The collective matches volunteers with community organizations across the city. Volunteers play with kids while their parents participate in and lead organizing efforts to defend community rights and build a better Chicago.

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

What is the Allied Media Conference (AMC)?

The AMC is an annual conference in Detroit (June 20-23) where individuals and groups come together to share tools and tactics for transforming our communities through media-based organizing.

Check out their website for more info -- http://alliedmedia.org/

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

So what is Chichico doing at AMC?

ChiChiCo is super psyched to be collaborating with other Childcare Collectives around the US to facilitate a whole 'track' of 11 workshops (including 'intergenerational storytelling' and 'outdoor games for love and liberation') for children ages 4-12. We're also providing childcare for children under 4 at the conference!

Each year, this annual fundraiser allows us to support a national movement of prioritizing kids by supporting the participation of parents and caregivers in community organizing, and by including kids in beautiful social justice work!

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

And Beyond!

Participating in AMC helps us to reenergize,  learn from other childcare collectives and organizers, and expand our support for both the Chicago community and other national childcare collectives. Each year we come home with new ideas for radical play and ways to sustain our work as Chichico. 

 

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

We are fundraising to cover the costs of:

$1000 for housing (4 nights for 8 people)

$300 for food and meals

$250 toward donation to AMC (as volunteers, we try to pay as much of the registration fee as we can to make the conference possible each year)

$250 for travel expenses (by car)

$100 for materials and supplies

$100 for indiegogo fees

GOAL: $2000

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

Other Ways You Can Help:

- Please forward this link to friends and talk about how important radical childcare is for children, parents, and our communities!

- Volunteer! We are always hoping to bring more folks in. http://www.chichico.org/volunteer/

To request childcare for your radical organizing event please visit our website or e-mail us at chichildcareco [at] gmail [dot] com

-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- 

See you at AMC!!!!

We are always hoping to bring more folks in. http://www.chichico.org/volunteer/To request childcare for your radical organizing event please visit our website or e-mail us at chichildcareco [at] gmail [dot] com-- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- ---- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- See you at AMC!!!!

story:
Our vision: “To create jobs by assisting Food Entrepreneurs to fulfill their dreams of a bold and vibrant business community.”

What We Need: 

Even though we've asked for $100,000.. $25,000 will help us to get the bigger funding that we need to build out a commercial kitchen.

Here's a video to watch of what a Kitchen Incubator is about - this just came out in the news. You'll have to click on the link to watch it..

CBC news story about Kitchen Incubators.

What You Get:

An opportunity to change the world by assisting our food producers develop their businesses. +a selection of perks as a way for us to say, a heartfelt Thank you. We do appreciate you from the bottom of our hearts. 

The Impact

The Kitchen Incubator will provide, classes, mentors and resources to help Food Start-Ups to be successful.

The services we'll be offering:

+ Shared Kitchen rentals, for Chefs, Food Trucks, Food Entrepreneurs

+ A Garden for the kitchen and the community

+ An Accelerator Cafe for Food businesses to sell their products at

+ Cooking classes, community workshops

+ Parties, food related events and community gatherings

+ Business Development program - with mentors

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE

If you can't give, we ask you to share this campaign with your  friends with personal emails,  blog about us, write  press releases, (yes they still work) share on your social networks.  Use the Indiegogo sharing buttons, on the far left side.

Become an Ambassador with Food 4 Social Change.  Go here.

And that's all there is to it.

Follow us:

Twitter: http://twitter.com/food4schange

Facebook: http://facebook.coom/food4socialchange

HOW DOES THIS FUNDRAISER WORK? 

The money you pledge will help us to move forward, to acquire more money from other sources, like a DPO. Building a commercial kitchen takes much more money and resources.  We are offering perks for your pledges. (Mailing & shipping is extra).

Whatever money we raise we keep,  the perks will be delivered at the end of the campaign. May 1, 2015.  Please help us achieve the dreams of food entrepreneurs a reality! 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The risks of not raising the money we need  for the Kitchen Incubator is that we fail the hundreds of food entrepreneurs who want to start a business of their own;  we fail to create jobs these people will provide; we fail to save new start-ups from launching.  The challenges are not finding great partners.

"The food incubator model has really grown from virtually very few food/kitchen incubators to about 10 in the last few years.  And why such growth? With the booming demand for specialty and artisan foods, incubators can help hungry Food Entrepreneurs to get started be a success in a licensed kitchen at a fraction of the cost of leasing and building a kitchen of their own. 

According to the National Incubation Association, “By mitigating start-up costs and providing a nurturing environment, business incubators have successfully graduated over 87% of their firms and kept an astounding 84% of these thriving businesses within their local communities for years after graduation. The culinary incubator, often referred to as a “shared-use commercial kitchen,” has taken a time-tested successful concept and swapped out office space for kitchens. They have opened to much acclaim, nurtured successful businesses and been embraced by their communities.

Thank you,

Mari-Lyn, Edie, Jan and Krishna

story:
Make art, get paid. Living the dream.

Puzzlebox Art Studio is a social enterprise created by Youth Connect, a vocational training program for young Burmese migrants in Mae Sot, Thailand. The studio began here on the Thai-Burma border in mid-2011 to help design the Picturebook Guesthouse—another Youth Connect social enterprise—with professional Thai, Burmese, and American artists hired to train apprentices.

Picturebook Guesthouse

For the full first year, students studied art daily, and worked with the professionals to design curtains, tiles, headboards, and bed runners for the guesthouse. After Picturebook opened in April 2012, Puzzlebox Art Studio became a standalone business, producing high-quality, quirky handmade products.

Puzzlebox not only teaches art skills, but also provides an atmosphere where young people learn life skills, develop critical thinking, and gain self-assurance. When they're ready to move on, we're confident that we've been a factor in their evolution, but of course are sorry to lose them. That leads to lack of continuity between staff artists, so two years ago we raised funds through Indiegogo to keep the teaching artists around longer than originally envisioned.

The Thai teacher Komol Kongcharoen left in May 2013, and the Burmese teacher Sein Sein Lin left in January 2014. The young artists now learn from each other, with additional art & English training supplied by manager Bobo. Our product design & quailty has reached new heights in the last year. But on the downside, our savings have run dangerously low. We desperately need your help to keep this one-of-a-kind business going.

What We Need & What You Get

We do our best to run the business on sales profits, but Mae Sot is a small town without many tourists, and the web business has been slow to build. Puzzlebox had no products to sell until mid-2012. We broke even in both 2013 and 2014, which is considered solid growth. Please help this growth continue as we reach out to more retail outlets and increase production throughout 2015.

Our products at NOVICA.com

We currently don't contact potential retailers as much as we should, nor do we promote our webshop as much as we should. This is because at our current level of production, we can't always keep up with orders, but we also can't increase production without more money. We're stuck.

Some example costs:
  • $25 - average monthly expense for batik materials, including dye, wax, and fabrics.
  • $50 - average monthly expense for ceramics materials, including clay, glaze, underglaze, gas for the kiln.
  • $150 - typical staff artist salary. This is considered fair for Mae Sot, but we'd love to improve it if possible. Artists work 5 days per week, with 24 days paid leave + 6 days sick leave, AND Thai holidays. We currently have 6 staff artists plus the manager. We'd like to hire more people AND raise salaries.
  • $170 - monthly rent. Unlike many small artisan producers, Puzzlebox is not family-run, nor can our work be done from home. Our staff artists collaborate, bounce ideas off each other, teach each other, all in an open-air studio with a big garden. We have a shop on the premises, and also conduct art workshops.
In addition, the ever-changing rules of Thai immigration means we're not sure what the next round of visas/work permits will cost for our staff.

PERKS: Let's be honest. We wouldn't be running this campaign if we could cover super-fancy incentives! Take a look at the smiles in our video, and consider that donating to an organization that provides fair-wage work in a relaxed, safe environment to bright young Burmese migrants may be reward in and of itself.


How does art improve migrant livelihoods?

Our current relationship with Youth Connect is informal. We partner with YC to train interns, give presentations, and short workshops for the "Stay in School" program.

We hire apprentices from Youth Connect just like many business in Mae Sot do, but we also strive to teach the staff how to better themselves, not to simply be painting machines. Youth Connect has a proven record of developing solid workers and community leaders, and we're proud of our links.

More than 20 apprentices and staff have passed through in the last 3 years. Some have started to run businesses themselves, some are teachers, some are translators. One of the featured artists in the video, John Khai, has worked with us for two years and will be leaving in 2015 to finally attend university. We're so excited for him, while at the same time, it's very difficult to lose someone of his caliber. Once again, we'll need money & time for training replacements.

Workshop with Singaporean artist LiLi Tan. Some of these artists have moved on.

Risks & Challenges

Life in Mae Sot can be volatile, and people randomly drift back and forth across the border. We can never be 100% certain that someone that we've poured time & money into training is going to stay on long-term. Having a safety net in our bank account buys us time, with which we can carefully consider our hiring choices. We want youths with the most potential and enthusiasm for building up Puzzlebox.

Two years ago, our campaign asked for a mere $4000. About $1000 was spent on an office computer, a sewing machine, and a serger. The remaining $3000 supplemented our sales for the last two years. We're not a charity, we're a business, and your donation would be considered an investment rather than a handout. Puzzlebox is now completely Burmese-run, and a new infusion of funds will last a long time.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • SHARE! Have a huge network of good-hearted friends who'd love to learn about Burmese-run social enterprise? Mae Sot is tiny, so we need all the publicity we can get!
  • BUY! Our goal is to make products that you love. Please take a look at our online shop. And if you see something on our Facebook page that isn't listed in the shop yet, email us with your inquiry!

story:
Thank You 

With the generous support of our fans and community, we were able to create a magical play & event space in our backyard last summer. It brought us much joy watching your children explore, invent, discover and dance & sing along with our talented line-up of musicians. Thank you to all of the families who chose our space to share your child's birthday with family and friends.

Throughout the inaugural season, we listened to ideas from customers, leading us to think of new ways that we could improve the space for exploration, safety and mid-day shade (yes, mid-day shade was very high on the request list). 

We made our decisions based on what features would have the greatest impact on your family's experience. In return for helping us raise the capital that we require for these additions, we are offering you discounts to playtimes, birthdays and in-store gift cards. You may purchase as many of any perk that you'd like.


The Additions

  • Beautiful, very large umbrellas for comfort in the mid-day heat
  • A water exploration area, including spouts and a hand pump 
  • An awesome 2'x5' peg board with with tons of wooden gears to explore and imagine with (it's a gigantic version of the one in our shop)
  • Removal of the 3-step staircase and the creation of a turfed slope for safer and easier access 
    *Avi's vote on the atrium with a retractable glass ceiling did not make the cut

For visual inspiration, please scroll down to the bottom. The umbrella is exact.
We have also included some photos from last season.


The Fine Print

  • We expect that these projects will cost between 11-14k
  • If we cannot reach our entire goal, we will complete as much as possible
  • If we exceed our goal of 11k-14k, thank you! We will use the funds for a couple of other great ideas (drinking fountain, coffee?!) 
  • We expect to open April 7th (Sing-a-longs will begin in May)
  • The entire season schedule will be posted on normanandjules.com
  • Packages and Perks do NOT expire
  • Please call with questions, it is important for us to know that you feel informed


Please Help Us Get The Word Out

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • @normanandjules #normanandjulesbackyard

story:
The Goal is to raise money and awareness for the fight against Cancer. Buy some socks or just donate.

ALL CONTRIBUTIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE via the International Myeloma Foundation

Everyone knows someone who’s been affected by Cancer, there’s never been a better time to help find a cure. This is your chance to get the official “Cancer Sucks” socks. They come in many colors and have become the standard for sockwear since introduced 4 years ago.

Music Against Myeloma was created in memory of Mark Rubin, who passed away from Multiple Myeloma at age 43 on Nov. 27th, 1993. With a goal to raise awareness and funds, Music Against Myeloma joins together with the International Myeloma Foundation to host this event.

Myeloma is an “oma,” or tumor, involving “myelo,” or blood-producing cells in the bone marrow. The cells affected are plasma cells (a type of white blood cell), which are antibody-(immunoglobulin-) producing cells. A cancerous plasma cell is called a myeloma cell. Myeloma is called “multiple” since there are frequently multiple areas in the bones where tumors have developed. More at www.myeloma.org

story:
Our Story "What ever we do, we do it for the kids!"

Our primary focus has been advocacy for the educational rights of disabled students in public schools, the education of parents and educators on the various aspects of each disability and requirements of educational law. Many years ago we just provided services for children with ADHD, now we do ALL disabilities, disorders and syndromes that affect the learning of the child or the teen. Find out more at our web site http://www.adhdservices.org/ where you can also download forms, checklists and resources that will assist you in your own advocacy efforts. You can also hear our CEO speaking weekly on special education topics on the Rose Moore Show at www.alltalkradio.net (The Rose Moore Show).


The Impact

We are currently focusing on one individual: Hannah Lowry.

Hannah Lowry is a 13 year old girl living in Las Vegas, Nevada.  She was first diagnosed with severe aplastic anemia in April 2008 when she was 9 years old.  Aplastic anemia is a rare disorder in which a person’s bone marrow fails, resulting in critically low levels of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.  After her initial diagnosis, Hannah was treated with immunosuppressant therapy for approximately one year and seemed to have overcome the disorder.  After nearly 2 years of normal blood levels, her condition returned in early 2011.  Her doctors have decided that her best option for treatment is a bone marrow transplant.

When Hannah was diagnosed in 2008, all immediate family members were tested to find a bone marrow donor, but none matched.  The recommended treatment for aplastic anemia when there are no related-donor matches for transplant is to undergo immunosuppressant therapy.  Hannah responded quickly to the drug therapy and was able to produce enough blood cells on her own without requiring transfusions after about one month of treatment.  She continued to improve over the next year, eventually returning to normal blood levels on her own without the help of drugs. 

For nearly 2 years after stopping the immunosuppressant therapy, Hannah was able to enjoy the normal life of a child.  She was able to attend school with her peers, participate in all activities and resume her gymnastics and tumbling classes.  Since her re-diagnosis in 2011, her life has changed drastically.  Due to her increased risk for bleeding and her suppressed immune system, Hannah has had to restrict or stop virtually all activities and remain at home since April 2011.

Early in 2011, during a routine blood check, it was discovered that her blood levels were dropping below normal levels again.  After several weeks of monitoring her blood levels, a bone marrow biopsy and aspiration were performed to confirm what was already expected:  the aplastic anemia had returned.  Since Hannah has already gone through the immunosuppressant therapy and has had a recurrence of the disorder, it was recommended that a search be conducted to find an unrelated bone marrow donor.  Since Nevada does not have a facility that performs the type of transplant she needs, Hannah was referred to the transplant team at Loma Linda University Medical Center in California.  Once a donor has been identified, Hannah will undergo chemotherapy and radiation to prepare her for the bone marrow transplant.  Since her own immune system will be completely destroyed, it is expected that she will be confined to the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit for at least 2 months following transplant while her new immune system is given time to develop.  After being released from the hospital, Hannah will need to remain in California for at least another 2 months in order to be near the transplant center for monitoring several times per week.  Once Hannah has recovered enough to be monitored by her doctor in Nevada, she will be allowed to return home to finish recovering.  Throughout the entire recovery process, great measures must be taken to ensure that she is not exposed to anything that could make her sick.  Her activities and environment will be heavily restricted and monitored for at least a year while her new immune system develops and becomes strong enough to protect her. 

As of June 1, 2011, Hannah is currently waiting for an unrelated donor match to be confirmed.  It is expected that the transplant process will begin in late June or early July, 2011.  In the meantime, Hannah is hospitalized to receive red blood cell and platelet transfusions about once per week when her levels drop too low.  She has been unable to physically attend school since April; however, she has been able to attend some of her classes via video conferencing.  Her goal is to be well enough by the fall of 2012 to begin high school with her peers.  

Tracking her Progress:     

You can hear about her progress and fundraising events though www.alltalkradio.net, www.adhdcas.org and through facebook at http://www.facebook.com/pages/ADHD-Child-Advocate-Services/188850371167749?sk=wall


Where The Profits Go

Everyone asks, "Where does the money go?". Understandably so, not a lot of people believe that 100% of the profits goes to the targeted reason, as most (not all) don't give you the break down. Well, this Non-profit company is well known in Nevada for never hoarding a penny of any donation given. So, with no regret or hidden agenda, here is the break down of where your money goes.

Donations made directly to this site:

This website states if we make our goal, it takes 10% of the total profits. My guess is to cover CC processing charges, transfer in back account, advertising, etc etc. Once it hits the ADHD CAS bank account, it is not touched until either 1) the deadlines of July 4th / July 30th OR 2) the goals are met. From there, 100% of the funds goes directly to Hannah's parents to pay for her treatments, medication, housing, transportation, sanitation and sterilization of any place she stays, education, etc. 

Donations coming from the TNT fireworks booth:

TNT was kind enough to provide us with a location, booth, and fireworks at a discounted rate. But there are fees that apply. We purchase the fireworks at 50% and sell them for 100% of its value. Whatever we don't sell we may return to TNT at our purchased price. There are a few items we must rent, and this is where donations of items comes in. Ie.  Renting a trailer to store our fireworks (Required by Fire and Safety laws) will cost about $200. The company it's currently on hold w is willing to give a discount, but hasn't given an estimate until upon return. If I can get someone to let us borrow an enclosed trailer based out of Las Vegas, that expense will go to Hannah Lowry rather than the rental cost. After all is said and done, and those expenses are paid out, 100% of the remaining funds will go to her. 

To view the list of items needed for the TNT fireworks booth please visit (we will update the list as items get donated):
http://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=188886017830851

If we don't get these items donated, we will have to take some of the profits from the event and pay the cost. Like all of you, we would rather have these items donated so more money goes to Hannah's treatments. 

 

We do want to make it clear that ADHD CAS will not take a cut of the profits from any event of donation directed to a specific client - being Hannah Lowry. If you would like to donate to ADHD CAS directly, please donate through paypal at https://www.paypal.com/us/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_flow&SESSION=SsY-Be2rdvuFMu09obPla2gborTLoSKl5zqiG5sSkpHGFSlB0IRmv6CLPfG&dispatch=5885d80a13c0db1f8e263663d3faee8d422be6d275c375afb284863ba74d6cdc

or mailing monies to our home office at 7516 Powder River Court. Las Vegas, NV 89131 and NOT through the Hannah Lowry fundraising website or events. Thank you.
